utterances: Let's see if we can talk to Linda, Linda with us from Muir Beach in California.
Hi.
I had a family vacation a couple of years ago in Costa Rica.
And we had signed up for a canopy cable ride in the - in the rainforest…
Mm-hmm.
…through the trees.
And my son and I went flying through the trees very successfully, and we're waiting on this little, tiny platform about 100 feet up.
And then my daughter came.
She was next.
And you're holding on - you have a harness, and you're holding on.
And she went zooming on this cable at about 35 miles an hour and couldn't brake herself.
She couldn't use the brake, the hand brake.
And she hit - she came in, and I saw her coming, and she couldn't stop into a tree.
She hit her head.
Ow.
And then, we were up 100 feet up, and she had to be lowered down with ropes and taken out on horseback, with us following her.
And the - at a certain point, the horse she was on - the people who were taking her, took a right turn and disappeared into the forest with her…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…and they had taken a short cut to the clinic.
But we didn't know that.
So there she was being - anyway, it all turned out okay.
She got stitches and she used her Spanish and was able to negotiate the clinic experience by herself.
What is Spanish for concussion?
That, I don't know.
Well - we'll maybe find out the word later on in the broadcast.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yes.
Linda, I'm glad everything turned out all right.
I didn't mean to laugh at your daughter's misfortune.
Well, it's been funny ever since for our family.
Yeah.
Thanks very much for the call.
You're welcome.
Bye-bye.
Let's go now to Paul, Paul with us from Cleveland.
Hi.
You know, I'll tell you, I thought my vacation from hell was hell.
But listening to your previous callers, I guess it was a walk in the park.
In 92, my family - my brother and I and my - our parents, we took a first all-family vacation to New York City for a long weekend.
And my co-workers thought I was insane.
I'd never gone anywhere with all four of my family.
And the fun started when Dad wasn't convinced that the Pennsylvania Turnpike ended at the New Jersey Turnpike, and questioned every bit of navigation that I had driving to New York City.

We were staying at an old college chum's third-floor walk-up in the Upper West Side, and it was on West 89th, and Dad started panicking because there was no address on any of the buildings that matched.
And only later did we find out we were one street away from where we needed to be.

And then, of course, my mother, who at the time, you know, was alive and had a medical emergency at 2 a.m. - she need colostomy supplies - that even in the city that doesn't sleep, we had to call Roosevelt Hospital, and I had to leave my wonderful parking spot and drive them across Manhattan to get to the hospital.
And God bless the staff at Roosevelt Hospital for providing the supplies she needed at 3 a.m.
And then our car was broken into on Washington Park because 230-pound me couldn't carry a two-pound video camera.
I left it in the trunk.
And, of course, the police said that five minutes after we left, they were sure the car was stolen - I mean, was broken into and robbed.
Didn't I see this picture?
Wasn't Jack Lemmon and Sandy Dennis in this picture?
Exactly.
Exactly.
Except that, you know, and my friends saw - when I got back to work, really, the worst part of it is I didn't get any sympathy from them because they said, you should have known better.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You had a great story, though.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
In a few minutes, 200 bands, 15 bars and four nights of pure bliss in the nation's car capital, Detroit.
That's coming up.
Well, it's a great story.
And I look on the positive side because down in that precinct of New York City, there were two major crimes that day.
Our family's car from Ohio broken into and two young ladies were driving in from New Jersey and they were kidnapped in their car, and that ended two blocks away in a hail of bullets.
So I'll take the lesser of those two crimes.
Losing the videotape recorder, not a problem.
Absolutely.
Thanks for the call, Paul.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
We're talking about disastrous family vacation stories.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And here's an email, this is from Julie in Phoenix.
My grandparents took my younger sister and me on a vacation to Disney World when I was in middle school.
It should have been a wonderful trip, but I got the stomach bug the night before we were scheduled to leave.
My grandpa inherited me - it from me the next day.
And once we got to Disney World, my poor little sister was violently ill inside Captain Nemo's yellow submarine, a small, enclosed space underwater and a long ride back to the exit.
Needless to say, none of us rides that ride anymore.
We can look back many years later and laugh about it, but none of us can think of a worse trip.
Let's go next to Kerry, Kerry with us from Oakdale in Connecticut.
Hey there, Neal.
Hi.
You know, when I was in the eighth grade, my family decided we were going to go to the Big Sky Country of Montana and stay on a working ranch - every eighth-grader's dream vacation, right?
Dude ranch, sure.
Of course.
So on our way there, we stopped at Yellowstone, and among other exciting things, my dad taking pictures of the buffalo dung to bring back to his friends.
We finally got to the working ranch, took a nice horseback ride, and stopped along the way to get some drink of water from the stream.
Get back and the next day, Kerry ends up with the lovely strep throat.
We had to drive three hours to the nearest town to get to the closest doctor, and then drive the three hours back to the ranch.
A couple days later, friends that I had made while at the ranch, we were sent to go get water because, you know, if you want to eat, you got to work on the working ranch.
And as we rounded the corner to come back to the kitchen, we came face to face with a great, big moose.
A moose?
A great, big one.
They're generally, you know, they're large and I guess a little scary, but they're generally not harmful.
No.
He turned around and walked the other way.
But, you know, to an eighth-grader and the other kid was probably in sixth grade, it was pretty - it was stop-in-your-tracks experience.
Okay.
And I'm sure the psychiatrist has managed to explain this all to you by now.
I'm sure he has.
But, you know, it's the most memorable vacation that I've had, despite the fact that as an eighth-grader, I did not want to go to a working ranch for my summer vacation.
Kerry, thanks very much for the call.
We hope the subsequent ones have been better.
(Soundbite of laughter)
They certainly have.
Thanks, Neal.
Have a good one.
